awd_titl_txt: CPS: Small: Collaborative Research: SecureNN: Design of Secured Autonomous Cyber-Physical Systems Against Adversarial Machine Learning Attacks
awd_abstract_narration:
Cyber-physical systems such as self-driving cars, drones, and intelligent transportation rely heavily on machine learning techniques for ever-increasing levels of autonomy. In the example of autonomous vehicles, deep learning or deep neural networks can be employed for perception, sensor fusion, prediction, planning, and control tasks. However powerful such machine learning techniques have become, they also expose a new attack surface, which may lead to vulnerability to adversarial attacks and potentially harmful consequences in security- and safety-critical scenarios. This project investigates adversarial machine learning challenges faced by autonomous cyber-physical systems with the aim of formulating defense strategies. The project will collaborate with the Center for STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Math) Education at Northeastern University and the Office of Access and Inclusion Center at University of California at Irvine to engage undergraduates, women, and minority students in independent research projects.

This project is composed of two interdependent research thrusts, one for investigating adversarial attacks and one for devising countermeasures, aiming to secure the key deep learning-equipped software components of autonomous cyber-physical systems, such as perception, obstacle prediction, and vehicle planning and control. The main deep learning techniques of interest to autonomous cyber-physical systems include convolutional neural networks for detection, recurrent neural networks for prediction, and deep reinforcement learning for control. The technical innovations of the project include ADMM (Alternating Direction Method of Multipliers) based attack generation, concurrent adversarial training and model compression, and multi-sourced defense schemes incorporating adversarial training and ensemble learning. This project will implement and evaluate the proposed attack and defense approaches on real-world prototypes of autonomous cyber-physical systems for autonomous vehicles and unmanned aerial vehicles in the investigators' labs. The investigators will release all the developed models, algorithms, and software to GitHub to facilitate community usage.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
This project successfully performed various novel security analysis and defense designs for autonmous Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) under adversarial machine learning (AML) attacks. On the intellectual merit side, this project (1) discovered a series of novel and practical AML attacks against critical AI/ML components in autonomous CPS context, e.g., against lane detection, person detection, object tracking, camera object detection, LiDAR object detection, camera-LiDAR fused object detection, and trajectory prediction; and (2) designs a series of novel methods to enable or enhance the defense strategyies against such attacks in autonmous CPS context, such as by improving its effectiveness (e.g., physical invariant-based attack detection and model enhancement, physical semantic-guided adversarial training), efficiency (e.g., concurrent adversrial training and weight pruning), and certified robustness (e.g., efficient bound-propagation for deep learning model robustness verification). These efforts led to 22 top-tier conference publications in total across the security community (1 * IEEE S&P, 2 * Usenix Security, 1 * NDSS), the machine learning community (3 * CVPR, 4 * ICCV, 2 * ECCV, 1 * ICLR, 2 * NeurIPS, 3 * AAAI, 1 * IJCAI), the robotics community (1 * IROS), and the software engineering community (1 * ICSE).

On the broader impacts side, this project made significant impacts to education/training, academic community, and the society through: (1) New course and course materials on machine learning security and autonomous CPS security in both undergraduate- and graduate-level courses across Northeastern University and UC Irvine; (2) Research mentoring, for 12 Ph.D. students and 15 B.S. students in total; (3) New academic workshop/conference organizing, for example co-founding the AutoSec (Automotive and Autonomous Vehicle Security) Workshop in 2019 and co-chairing it annually, co-chairing the IEEE SafeThings Workshop in 2021, and co-founding the ISOC Symposium on Vehicle Security and Privacy (VehicleSec) in 2023, which is the first official academic conference dedicated to vehicle security and privacy topics; (4) New security competition organizing, for example the first AutoDriving CTF (Capture-The-Flag) competition in 2021 at DEFCON (one of the world's largest and most notable hacker convention), and the annual organization of it every year since then; (5) Media coverage, for example by MIT Tech Review, The New Yorker, Communication of the ACM, WIRED, ACM TechNews, etc.; (6) Invited talks at various academia conferences, unversities, and industry companies, including a keynote at CPSS'21, DSML'22, and AUTOSAR Open Conference'23; and (7) Source code/data release, for example those on https://github.com/ASGuard-UCI.

For all the security vulnerabilities discovered in this project, the PI performed extensive responsible vulnerability disclosure to potentailly affected industry developers/companies on autonomous CPS. These efforts led to significant industry impacts, for example triggered over 30 autnomous vehicle companies to start investigating the security vulnerabilities newly-discovered in this project, among which some companies confirmed to work on fixes. The PI is also invited to perform vulnerability disclosure at Auto-ISAC (Automotive Information Sharing & Analysis Center), which has 50+ company members including light- and heavy-duty vehicle OEMs, suppliers and the commercial vehicle sector.


Last Modified: 02/29/2024
Modified by: Qi Chen
